name: White: 1. e4 Complete Repertoire
description: Complete 1. e4 repertoire covering all major Black responses: Italian Game vs 1...e5, Alapin vs Sicilian, Advance vs French/Caro-Kann, and straightforward play vs the Scandinavian.

tree.explanation: The King's Pawn Opening. We stake a claim in the center, open diagonals for our bishop and queen, and prepare to develop quickly. This is the most popular first move in chess.

children.explanation: The Open Game. Black mirrors our central control. This leads to the Italian Game, Spanish, and other classical openings.
Developing with a threat! Our knight attacks e5, forcing Black to defend. This is the most principled move.
The most common defense. Black develops a piece and protects e5.
The Italian Game! Our bishop targets the weak f7 square (only defended by the king) and prepares to castle. This is one of the oldest and most natural openings.
The Giuoco Piano ('Quiet Game'). Black develops symmetrically, also eyeing f2. This is the most solid response.
Preparing d4 to build a big pawn center. This is the main line, leading to rich strategic play.
Developing and attacking our e4 pawn. Now we must decide: quiet play with d3 or sharp play with d4.
The Giuoco Pianissimo ('Very Quiet Game'). We solidly protect e4 and plan slow maneuvering: Nbd2-f1-g3 to pressure Black's kingside. This is recommended for beginners - safe and strategic.
Solid. Black reinforces e5 and prepares to develop.
Castle early, castle often! Our king is safe and rook is connected. Next: Nbd2, then Nf1-g3.
Both sides have castled. A typical middlegame position.
The knight heads to f1, then g3 or e3. From g3, it eyes f5 and h5. This slow buildup is typical of the Pianissimo.
Black prepares ...Ba7 (keeping the bishop safe from b4 ideas) and ...b5 to expand on the queenside.
Castle first, then continue development. We're not worried about Black's slow plan.
The sharp approach! We strike in the center immediately. This leads to open, tactical positions. Good if you like complications.
Black captures, opening the position.
We recapture with the pawn, maintaining the center.
A slower approach. Black solidifies e5 before developing the knight.
We strike now while Black hasn't developed the kingside knight. This gives us a strong center.
The Evans Gambit! We sacrifice a pawn to deflect Black's bishop and gain rapid development. Very aggressive and fun, but requires knowing the theory.
Black accepts. Declining (4...Bb6) lets us play c3 and d4 with an extra tempo.
Attacking the bishop and preparing d4. Black must retreat, giving us time.
The main retreat. The bishop stays active on the a5-e1 diagonal.
Mission accomplished! We have a powerful center and open lines. Our lead in development compensates for the pawn.
The Two Knights Defense. Black counterattacks immediately, ignoring the f7 threat. This is more aggressive than 3...Bc5.
The Knight Attack! We immediately threaten Nxf7, forking queen and rook. If Black doesn't know the correct defense, they can lose quickly. Very dangerous at beginner levels.
The only good move! Black blocks our bishop's view of f7. Any other move loses.
We capture, opening lines and maintaining the threat.
A BLUNDER! This is the move beginners always play, and it loses to the Fried Liver Attack. Strong players avoid this.
THE FRIED LIVER ATTACK! We sacrifice the knight to drag the king out. Black is in serious trouble.
Forced. The king must capture.
Check! And we attack the undefended knight on d5. Black is lost - they'll have to give up material or get mated.
The king tries to defend the knight. It looks absurd, but it's the only try.
Developing with attack on the knight. White has a crushing position - the black king is completely exposed.
The Polerio Defense. The correct move! Black attacks our bishop instead of recapturing. This is what strong players do.
We save the bishop with check. The game becomes very sharp and theoretical from here.
Blocking the check and attacking our pawn.
We capture, opening lines. The position is very sharp with chances for both sides.
Black recaptures. They're down a pawn but have active pieces and attacking chances.
The bishop retreats. We're a pawn up with a complex game ahead.
The quiet approach against the Two Knights. We avoid the sharp Ng5 lines and just develop solidly. Good if you want a calmer game.
Now we transpose to Giuoco Pianissimo positions. A solid game for both sides.
The Hungarian Defense. Very solid but passive. Black avoids all complications.
We seize the center immediately. Black's passive setup gives us free rein.
The Paris Defense / Semi-Italian. Solid but slow. Black reinforces e5 before developing.
Strike in the center while Black is slow. We get a nice space advantage.
The Philidor Defense. A solid but slightly passive choice. Black defends e5 with a pawn instead of developing a piece.
Challenge the center immediately! Black must deal with the tension.
The most common continuation. Black develops and attacks e4.
Solid development, defending e4. We have more space and a strong center.
Black exchanges. This releases the tension but gives us a free hand in the center.
We recapture. Our knight is centralized and we have easy development ahead.
The Petrov Defense (Russian Game). Black counterattacks instead of defending e5. This leads to symmetrical, drawish positions at high levels, but beginners can go wrong.
We simply capture the pawn. Black should NOT immediately recapture...
The correct response. Black kicks our knight and will recapture on e4 next.
We retreat. The position is equal but we have easy play.
Black recovers the pawn. The game is level.
Grabbing space in the center. Simple chess ahead.
A common beginner mistake! This loses material after our queen check.
Pinning the knight to the king! Black is in trouble.
The Sicilian Defense - Black's most popular and ambitious response to 1.e4. Black fights for the d4 square from the flank. We'll play the Alapin (2.c3) to avoid massive theory.

The Alapin Variation! Instead of entering Black's theoretical maze with 2.Nf3 Nc6/d6 3.d4, we prepare to build an ideal pawn center with d4. This frustrates Sicilian players who want sharp tactical games.
The main response. Black strikes back immediately while we can't play Nc3 to attack the queen.
We capture. Taking is best - advancing e5 lets Black equalize easily.
Black recaptures with the queen. Normally this is bad (early queen development), but here we can't chase it with Nc3.
Mission accomplished! We have our ideal center. Now we develop rapidly.
Natural development, controlling e4.
Solid development. If Black plays ...cxd4, we get an Isolated Queen Pawn (IQP) position - good for attacking players!
Black solidifies and prepares ...Be7 or ...Bd6.
Developing and reinforcing d4. We're slightly better with more space and easy play.
Black pins our knight, trying to disrupt our center.
Simple unpinning. We continue with normal development.
Black attacks e4 immediately, hoping to lure it forward.
We accept! We gain space and kick the knight. Black will be cramped.
The knight retreats to the only good square.
Seizing the center as planned.
Black exchanges to relieve the pressure.
The modern approach. We develop before recapturing, keeping Black guessing.
Black prepares ...d6 to challenge our e5 pawn.
Now we recapture. We have a space advantage and easy development.
A mistake! This lets us achieve the ideal center.
We get our perfect center. Black cannot prevent this after 2...Nc6.
The French Defense. Black prepares ...d5 with support. The downside is the light-squared bishop gets blocked behind the pawns.
Taking the center. Now Black will play ...d5.
The typical French pawn structure emerges.
The Advance Variation! We grab space and lock the center. Black's light bishop is now permanently restricted. This is simple and effective for beginners.
Black attacks our pawn chain at its base - a standard French plan.
We reinforce d4. Our pawn chain is solid.
Black develops and adds pressure to d4.
Solid development, defending d4.
Black pressures d4 and b2.
Preparing to castle. We can also play a4 to gain space on the queenside.
The Caro-Kann Defense. Like the French, Black prepares ...d5, but keeps the light bishop free. Very solid.
Standard. We take the center.
Now Black challenges our center.
The Advance Variation - same idea as vs the French! We gain space. The difference is Black's bishop isn't blocked here.
Black develops the bishop before it gets trapped. This is the key advantage of the Caro over the French.
Simple development. We'll castle short and have a space advantage.
Black solidifies and prepares ...c5.
Preparing to castle. We have a slight edge due to space.
Black strikes immediately at our chain.
Reinforcing d4. Same structure as the French Advance.
The Scandinavian Defense. Black immediately challenges our center, but brings the queen out early. We can exploit this.
Always capture! If we play e5 instead, Black develops easily.
The main line. Black's queen comes out early - we'll attack it.
Developing with tempo! The queen must move again.
The most popular retreat. The queen stays active but safe.
We seize the center. Black has a knight out; we have a pawn center and developed knight.
Black develops.
Natural development.
Black creates a retreat square on c7 for the queen.
A clever move! The bishop eyes a5, potentially winning tempi with Nc3-b5 ideas later. We have a pleasant advantage.
Black develops the bishop actively before playing ...e6.
Active development, eyeing f7. We're slightly better.
The 'Banker' retreat - all the way back. Solid but very passive.
We get the center for free. Nice advantage.
The Gubinsky-Melts Defense. The queen stays central but can be awkward.
Standard. We have a great position.
The Modern Scandinavian. Black develops before recapturing. Less common but playable.
We keep the pawn and grab the center. If Black takes on d5, we develop with tempo.
Black recovers the pawn.
Kicking the knight and gaining space.
Alekhine's Defense. Black invites us to push the pawn and attack the knight. The knight will hop around while we overextend (in theory). Unusual but playable.
We accept the challenge and chase the knight.
The knight retreats to its only good square.
We build a strong center. This is the main line.
Black challenges our center.
Solid development. We maintain our space advantage.
The Pirc Defense. Black will fianchetto the king's bishop and let us build a big center, then attack it later. Hypermodern approach.
We take the full center. Classical play.
Black develops, preparing ...g6 and ...Bg7.
We develop and reinforce our center.
The Pirc setup begins.
The Austrian Attack - the most aggressive response. We prepare to storm the kingside.
The Modern Defense. Similar to the Pirc but even more flexible. Black will fianchetto and wait to see our setup.
Grab the center. Don't be shy!
The fianchetto is complete.
Simple development. We have a big center and easy play.
